title: #94 – Mark Hyman M.D.: The impact of the food system on our health and the environment
content:
In this episode, Mark Hyman, M.D., director of the Cleveland Clinic Center for Functional Medicine and the author of Food Fix, discusses that if we can fix the food system, we can solve many big problems—namely the chronic disease/obesity epidemic, the rising costs of healthcare, as well as the big problems facing the environment. Mark first briefly lays out the health consequences of processed food with a focus on the gut microbiome. From there, Mark discusses the environmental consequences of industrial farming and lays out how we can affect change on the individual level, through policy and regulations, and perhaps most importantly through regenerative agriculture. Additionally, Mark talks about the potential health risks of consuming GMO foods, herbicides, and other chemicals used in industrial farming as well as the environmental consequences, such as the loss of soil, caused by those same fertilizers and methods of farming.

            Show NotesThe negative consequences of the existing food environment [3:25]
Why did Mark decide to go into food research?

As a doctor seeing patients day after day for 30 years, as a functional medicine doctor, my focus is on why are my patients so sick? 

The majority of them, it has some relationship to food. 
I had to figure out why are they eating the food they’re eating?
The food system we have is the problem


–Why do we have this food system?

It’s because of the food policies.


–Why do we have our food policies? 


It’s the food industry that influences our government policies through lobbying and other influences that they do across the spectrum of society to drive their products to the market and sell them.



“There’s 11 million people that die every year from eating ultra processed food and not enough of the good food. And I think it’s an underestimate.”
The answer as to why Mark decided to focus on this issue: “I realized I couldn’t fix my patients in my office or in the hospital, or the clinic I had to go to where the source of the problem was.”
Was the evolution of farming all bad?

No, in fact, Mark says that, “agriculture is a solution, if we do it right.”

The main pillars making the current food environment “toxic”

Chronic disease: Food is the biggest driver of chronic disease affecting six out of 10 people
Economic crisis: It’s clearly the biggest driver of economic stress in this country, in our $22 trillion debt. 

One third of all Medicare expenses are for diabetes alone
One third of all of our federal budget is Medicare
And if it was a company, it would be the biggest company in the world at $1 trillion annually. 


Climate change: It’s also driving climate change. 

A food system, end-to-end, is the number one cause of climate change more than fossil fuels, says Mark
It’s causing massive environmental degradation including loss of bio-diversity (plant species, animal species, livestock species) 
And of course that leads to massive political instability because of our food system of climate refugees, because the food system is driving climate. 

The UN estimates that within a decade or few decades we’re going to have 200 to a billion climate refugees




Social injustice: It’s driving social injustice in many ways through how it affects our kids’ cognitive development and ability to learn (And there’s huge academic achievement gaps)

It leads to massive health disparities because poor communities are more affected by these foods and are more targeted by them. 


Cognitive behavioral issues: Violence, conflict, depression, suicide

And I think our diet has changed so radically, not just in the last 10,000 years, but in the last 40 years with the advent of massive amounts of ultra processed food and that’s driving cognitive behavioral issues, violence, suicide, conflict, etc.


National security: It even threatens our national security because 70% of military recruits are unfit to fight and they are rejected

The good news?

All these issues are connected by food, they can all be solved by going to the root and fixing our food system. 

 
What makes processed food so unhealthy? [9:00]
Is there really anybody who does NOT believe that processed food is terrible for us?

Mark says you’d be surprised, “There’s $12 billion spent by the food industry on nutrition ‘research’ that confuses peoples, muddies the waters, declares that Gatorade is a great sports drink and that sugar doesn’t cause obesity.”
Academics, doctors, health professionals have no clue how powerful food is to heal disease. 
Most people just think that if you eat too much, you’re going to get fat
We have a real lack of understanding of the power of food to cause disease and the power of food to cure disease. 
Something like medicare for all would bankrupt the country, says Mark, “because everybody’s sick and it’s going to bankrupt the country unless we fix why they’re sick in the first place.”

What do you think it is about processed foods that are particularly difficult metabolically for our species?

Historically we ate ~800 different species of plants

We at almost 100 g of fiber per day
Now we average about 8 grams of fiber per day


Sugary foods are so easy to get (in contrast to what the Naaplese honey hunters must endure)
The development of industrial agriculture was a huge positive in the post-war world and created an abundance of calories that solved hunger issues around the world
HOWEVER… the unintended consequence of the intensive chemical agriculture with intensive fertilizer use and the commodity products (wheat, corn and soy and rice) was the obesity epidemic
Our biology isn’t adapted to eating highly refined foods

Yet, it’s ~60% of our calories
And every 10% of your calories that’s ultra processed food, your risk of death goes up by 14%


And that’s not to mention other stuff in processed foods and industrial farmed produce that may be problematic like:

refined soybean oil
food additives
chemicals 
BPA from plastics
Other metabolic toxins
pesticides and glyphosate affecting our microbiome



“Sugar and starch and flour are the big drivers, but there’s all these other components. And then who knows what’s happening with pesticides and glyphosate affecting our microbiome. I mean it’s such a complex web of different factors that alter our metabolic pathways that drives disease.”
Energy balance (too much) vs. void of nutrients (too much junk food)]
How much of the problem with processed food is about a lack of nutrients and fiber vs. an energy balance problem?

Probably both, says Mark
It’s well known that if you are looking for nutrients, you’re just going to eat anything (e.g., kids with Pica will eat dirt)

-Refined starches and sugars affect your biology:

They raise insulin, which has a cascading effect of fat storage in your belly, which is a dangerous fat. 
It leads to increased hunger, affects your brain chemistry. 
It actually locks the fat in the fat cells so that can’t get out. 
It slows your metabolism. 
So you’re in this cascade of vicious cycles.

-In terms of energy balance…

Most people think about calories in, calories out
But it’s more complex than that
There’s different effects of food on your biology, independent of calories. 
750 calories of Coke is NOT the same as 750 calories of broccoli, for example, they have profoundly different effects on your biology
But we don’t really appreciate that medicine and most of our current thinking about weight loss is focused on calories in, calories out. 

-The Food industry loves to push the “calories in, calories out” narrative:

They say, “it’s all about moderation. There’s no good or bad calories. It’s exercise more, eat less.”
But the truth is that these foods affect our brain chemistry and create all sorts of metabolic issues that are incredibly difficult. 
Neurologist David Perlmutter just wrote a book called Brain Wash, which explains the prefrontal cortex and the amygdala are uncoupled with an inflammatory diet

The prefrontal cortex, which is the decision maker, understands the consequences of his behavior, is not talking to the amygdala which is the impulse part of your brain (the fight or flight part of your brain, the pleasure seeking part of the brain)



“We have so much bad behavior and conflict and so forth because we’re eating this inflammatory diet that’s literally dysregulating our brains. So the adult in the room is asleep.”
What is it about processed food and sugars that could cause inflammation?

There is a lot of genetic variability from person to person in terms of their tolerance
But anyone will do better when eating a whole foods, unprocessed diet
You can actually measure inflammation in response to diet through various biomarkers through CRP or SED rate
Insulin is another inflammation driving hormone

Processed foods drive up insulin which leads to visceral belly fat
Mark calls this a “metabolic fire” that starts in these cells and it spreads inflammation throughout the body



–What if tests for CRP and interleukins came back normal? Could there still be an inflammatory response?

Mark says our current tools for assessing the immune response to food are “pretty crappy”
Fortunately, there’s this whole new panel of inflammatory biomarkers that are much more specific and much more sensitive and it enables us to really look at the inflammatory response that’s happening in the body (see Buck Institute of Aging) 

 
The gut microbiome: Inflammation from gut permeability, and how to measure gut health [18:30]
Peter’s take on inflammation and the gut:

Peter admits that there current protocol for trying to fix subtle elevations in fibrinogen and/or C reactive protein or at least two of the interleukins is “crude”
It’s basically a elimination diet where you take thing away and keep an eye on the biomarkers
And the real problem is we don’t know exactly the mechanism by which we are seeing these inflammatory markers rise
One possibility is gut permeability 

Does Mark think gut permeability is a prevalent source of inflammation?

It’s a huge source, says Mark
“All our guts are messed up”
There’s a well-studied phenomenon called metabolic endotoxemia

-The gut microbiome has a huge role in regulation of weight (independent of calories)

⇒ This experiment shows you can take the poop out of a obese rat and put it into a skinny rat and make it fat

–Your microbiome is regulated by what you eat:

The amount of (or lack thereof) fiber, prebiotics, the phytonutrients, phytochemicals, the polyphenols all affect the quality of the “garden” you have growing inside of you
And you can get a lot of “nasty weeds” in there

-Additionally…

Our low fiber, high sugar, high processed food diets increase bad bugs in the gut
Antibiotics, acid blockers, antiinflammatory drugs, hormones all screw up our gut as well
And environmental toxins, such as glyphosate, is super toxic to the microbiome

-When all this starts to happen…

They start to disrupt the gut microbiome
They disrupt the lining of the gut. 
They cause what we call “leaky gut”
This allows the absorption of bacterial products, bacterial toxins as well as food antigens
And they start to create an inflammatory response
This is partly a problem because about 60% of your immune system is in your gut

–An interesting discovery:

At least a third of our metabolites in our blood may be from microbiome
And these non-human bacteria that are regulating your immune system, activating your mitochondria, regulating your DNA, affecting your brain chemistry (mood), and affecting all sorts of diseases. 

“This is like a really exciting area and I think getting people’s microbiome sorted often happens when you shift to a whole-foods, plant-rich diet.”
How does one measure gut health?
“It’s a challenge because you are looking at a moving target, an ecosystem” says Mark
-Many different biomarkers to assess what’s going on in the gut:

Is there adequate pancreatic enzyme function looking at pancreatic elastase? 
Are there absorption issues? 
Looking at fecal fats, are there inflammatory markers in there? 

For example, calprotectin or eosinophil protein X, which are standard markers to look at inflammation in the gut. 


What’s your IGA levels, your antibody levels? 
Indicators of dysregulated gut microbiome – such as low levels of short chain fatty acids

Short chain FA are essentially produced by good bacteria that are the fuel for the gut
They have anticancer & antiinflammatory properties
Example would be having low levels of butyrate


You can also look for different microbiome characteristics using DNA, or PCR analysis through the microRNAs

For example, levels of Akkermansia


You can also look at gut culture for parasites (PCR testing)

“There’s a lot of things that we look at and get a gestalt. It changes over time, but you can see if someone’s got a good gut, or okay gut, or a terrible gut.”
 
Steps to fixing a bad gut—The Five R’s [24:30]

REMOVE
REPLACE
REINOCULATE
REPAIR
RESTORE

Step 1: Remove

Remove foods that may be triggering a problem like:

Gluten, which affects permeability
Dairy
Grains for some people


Remove “bad bugs”

Some people have a parasite (Mark recently gave a woman Alinia, antiparasitic medication, for six days and she felt better after suffering for 20 years)
Other people may have bacterial overgrowth or yeast overgrowth that needs to be removed



Step 2: Replace

Replace what might be missing
Fiber, prebiotics, enzymes, various things that may be needed to support the system.
You can take supplements or eat prebiotic foods like plantain and artichokes

Step 3: Reinoculate

Provide probiotics where necessary. 
And that can be through foods like fermented foods or can be through probiotic supplements. 

Step 4: Repair

The body may need certain nutrients to heal:

Glutamine
Vitamin A
Fish oil
Butyrate
Polyphenols from food (pomegranate, cranberries, green tea, etc.)

“We thought it was prebiotics and probiotics, but turns out the polyphenols in plant foods are super helpful for the gut microbiome.”





Step 5: Restore

Restore your nervous system, says Mark

For example, high stress levels can cause a leaky gut


This article also adds…

Be mindful of: Sleep, The way you approach and eat food, Your emotions, Exercise, and Stress ⇒ These can all affect the GI tract
Also, activate your vagus nerve for digestive health



 
Some staggering health statistics, and which races might be more genetically susceptible [27:15]
Some staggering statistics: (ref)

6 out of 10 Americans have a chronic disease
4 out of 10 have two or more chronic diseases
In 10 years, 83 million Americans with have 3 or more
1 in 2 Americans has prediabetes or type 2 diabetes
75% of us are overweight
Most states now have 40% obesity rates

“These are massive things that are happening at a scale that we’ve never seen in history, that we haven’t been equipped to deal with, that we haven’t really thought of how to address. And it’s like we’re trying to scramble to fix it.”
Are there genetic differences that make certain races of people more susceptible?

Genetically, there’s certain segments of the population that are more susceptible to getting obesity and diabetes when they’re in an abundance of sugar and flour
That includes

Native Americans (probably the most susceptible)
African Americans
Latinos
South Pacific islanders
People from India, China, and Asians people often are at much higher risk even at lower body rates



 
An argument for government regulations and policies to fight back against a massive food industry with unlimited resources (and what we can learn from the tobacco story) [29:00]
Is there any country or government in particular that seems more attuned to this problem than the American government?

“Many. In fact, most.” says Mark

⇒ Chile, for example, is attempting to address the massive obesity rates in kids and adults and the staggering healthcare cost in the following ways:

Taxing soda
Warning labels on bad food
No cartoon characters can be used to advertise to kids
eliminated any processed foods from school lunches
eliminated any advertising on junk food from 6am until 10pm
the restriction of food marketing and the warning label and so forth had a fourfold increased benefit compared to the soda tax

What can we learn from the successful campaign against smoking cigarettes?



Some might argue the marketing restrictions would violate the First Amendment
The US has faced an analogous situation with smoking
Smoking ads weren’t outright banned, but they were forced to run a counter-ad about the dangers of smoking immediately following the advertisement
The counter ad was so devastating to tobacco companies that they basically volunteered to stop running ads at all
Prior to the Surgeon General saying publicly that cigarettes are causing lung cancer, about 55% of the people over 18 years smoked 
That has dropped to about 16% currently 
Peter brings this up as a “work around” rather than going down the fight against the First Amendment 
It would almost be like a drug commercial⇒ “You can eat this soda, but it’s going to cause obesity, diabetes, cancer, dementia, and kill you early.”


Perhaps the successful fight against the tobacco industry offers a playbook that can be followed?

The food industry is stalling the regulations

Mark says that the food industry is actually copying the tobacco industry’s playbook to slow or stall or stop this

–Example #1: Subversive tactics to avoid the soda taxes that passed in California 

The American Beverage Association went to California and put in a ballot measure, which was designed to prohibit local taxes unless it was a two thirds majority

Meaning you couldn’t fund your school, your police department, your fire department, your cleanup, road clean unless there was a two thirds majority. That would hamper local governments dramatically. 


And they spent millions of dollars pushing this ballot measure even though it had nothing to do with food.
Next, at the last minute before the election, they went to Governor Jerry Brown and told him, “Look, we’ll pull this measure, but you have to put in place a preemptive law that prohibits any future taxes on soda or junk food.” 
This is exactly what tobacco did.

–Example #2: An initiative called the Global Energy Balance Network, GEBN

The GEBN’s mantra was that all calories were the same and it was simply about moderation and calories in/calories out
Rhona Applebaum (VP at Coca-Cola) ran GEBN and she found a bunch of scientists (like James Hill) who she could co-op, paid them lots of money, and funded research to actually promote the idea that all calories are the same
Eventually it was discovered what they were doing and the NY Times reported it
After the NY Times article came out they shut down the GEBN

⇒ Here’ is the NY Times article by Anahad O’Connor: Coca-Cola Funds Scientists Who Shift Blame for Obesity Away From Bad Diets
“It just goes to show how these food companies are co-opting scientists co-opting professional associations, co-opting social groups, co-opting the government, putting forth front groups and spinning all kinds of misinformation in a very coordinated strategic strategy to disrupt public opinion, to confuse the public, and to allow their shenanigans to keep going.” 
Should we try to solve this on the individual level instead of the government level?
-Why not focus all of the efforts on helping individual people understand the harm of this food so that they can make the informed choice?
-Do we really believe that this has to be solved at the level that seems almost unwinnable, which is fighting an unethical opponent with infinite resources?

Mark points out it worked against the tobacco industry
Peter: “But you don’t need tobacco to live, right?…The advantage that you would have as an anti-tobacco crusade person is the ground is not muddied by the notion that tobacco is part of a group called food that you need to live.”

–Would we be better off putting more effort into sort of the grassroots campaign to inform individuals versus using public policy?

Mark says that we must do both
People are starting to change some of their eating habits and forcing companies to create healthier product lines 
“But that alone is not enough because there are structural problems that are not solvable unless we change how we grow food, what we grow, how we process, distribute, market, sell, eat and waste it.”

 
Industrial farming and climate change: The degradation of soil and use of fertilizer [41:45]
“Does fixing food fix climate? It does. It’s actually one of the only ways to really reverse climate change.”
Some climate change stats:

A million acres flooded in the Midwest, crop land, it’s destroying farmer’s livelihood
Increasing weather patterns of hurricanes and wildfires in Australia and California. 
Melting of three trillion tons of ice from Antarctica

–Peter’s two cents:

I think the term climate change, global warming, were not the best ways to describe this phenomenon
Climate volatility would have been a better way to have explained it because i) it’s actually more accurate, and ii) it provides a better explanation for what you are describing

Why is it happening and what’s the cause of it?

Most people think it’s fossil fuels taking up all the carbon that was stored in the Earth’s crust and burning it and releasing that carbon 
That’s about ⅓ of the reason, says Mark

-Half of climate change comes from our food system through all sorts of different mechanisms:
   1—Deforestation, you lose the carbon capture from the trees
   2—Soil destruction from destructive agriculture

The industrial growing of food tills the soil and which disrupts the normal organic matter and causes soil erosion which releases carbon in the environment

More about the soil
